perturbation.original_text: Confidential Information means any proprietary or confidential information, technical data, trade secrets or know-how, including research, product plans, products, services, customer lists and customers, markets, software, developments, inventions, processes, formulas, technology, designs, drawings, engineering, marketing, distribution and sales methods and systems, sales and profit figures, finances and other business information disclosed by a Party or its Representatives ("Disclosing Party") to the other Party or its Representatives ("Receiving Party"), whether in writing, orally or by drawings or inspection of documents or other tangible property; provided that: (i) Confidential Information shall not include any of the foregoing items to the extent that (1) they are or have become publicly known and made generally available through no wrongful act of Receiving Party, (2) they were known to Receiving Party prior to disclosure by Disclosing Party, as evidenced by pre-existing written records promptly provided to Disclosing Party by Receiving Party, (3) they were disclosed to Receiving Party without an obligation of confidentiality by a third party having a lawful right to make such disclosure, or (4) they were developed by Receiving Party without use or aid of Disclosing Party's Confidential Information, and (ii) the results of the Research (including the contents of each Report and any Inventions) shall be deemed to be LBIO's Confidential Information, subject to MD Anderson's right to publish any Research data and information as set forth in and in accordance with Section 6.4, MD Anderson's right to use any Inventions (and any Work) as set forth in and in accordance with Section 7.2, and MD Anderson's right to use any Research data and information for internal research, academic, and non-commercial patient care purposes prior to publication or public disclosure and for any purpose thereafter. LBIO shall be deemed the Disclosing Party with respect to such results of the Research, regardless of the Party initially disclosing the same.
perturbation.changed_text: Confidential Information means any proprietary or confidential information, technical data, trade secrets or know-how, including research, product plans, products, services, customer lists and customers, markets, software, developments, inventions, processes, formulas, technology, designs, drawings, engineering, marketing, distribution and sales methods and systems, sales and profit figures, finances and other business information disclosed by a Party or its Representatives ("Disclosing Party") to the other Party or its Representatives ("Receiving Party"), whether in writing, orally or by drawings or inspection of documents or other tangible property; provided that: (i) Confidential Information shall not include any of the foregoing items to the extent that (1) they are or have become publicly known and made generally available through no wrongful act of Receiving Party, (2) they were known to Receiving Party prior to disclosure by Disclosing Party, as evidenced by pre-existing written records promptly provided to Disclosing Party by Receiving Party, (3) they were disclosed to Receiving Party without an obligation of confidentiality by a third party having a lawful right to make such disclosure, or (4) they were developed by Receiving Party without use or aid of Disclosing Party's Confidential Information, and (ii) the results of the Research (including the contents of each Report and any Inventions) shall be deemed to be LBIO's Confidential Information, MD Anderson will however maintain the right to disclose such Confidential information and will act as the Disclosing Party with respect to such results of the Research, regardless of the Party initially disclosing the same.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by stating that the LBIO's data is confidential, yet MD Anderson can disclose it, also the text says MD Anderson is the Disclosing Party regarding this data, shifting the obligations of confidentiality defined elsewhere in this section.

perturbation.original_text: MD Anderson shall, and shall cause each of its employees, agents, contractors, and subcontractors performing Research activities or other obligations under this Agreement, including the Principal Investigator (collectively, "Representatives") to, conduct such activities, and use, store and handle all materials used in the performance of activities under this Agreement and each Study Order, or cause the same to be done, in accordance with (i) all applicable laws, regulations, and guidelines, including, to the extent applicable, the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act ("FFCDA"); the anti-kickback and related provisions of the Social Security Act; the Public Health Services Act; the regulations promulgated by the Food and Drug Administration ("FDA"), including 21 C.F.R. Parts 50, 56, and 58, and, with respect to clinical Studies, the requirements of the Statement of Investigator, FDA Form 1572 (as described in 21 312.53), the terms of which are incorporated by reference into any Study Order pertaining to a clinical Study (and the Principal Investigator for any such clinical Study shall complete, sign, and deliver a Form 1572 to LBIO prior to the commencement of such Study); the United States Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, as amended by the HITECH Act, including the Standards for Privacy of Individually Identifiable Health Information; the EU Data Protection Directive; and all other applicable privacy, security and data protection laws (collectively, this sub-clause (i), "Laws"), and, as applicable, the quality standards of "Good Clinical Practice" (which term shall mean generally accepted good clinical practices including those set out in the current version of the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice in force from time to time and FDA's most recent guidance and regulations concerning current Good Clinical Practice), (ii) the provisions of this Agreement (including each applicable Study Order and Protocol), and (iii) all written instruction from LBIO, as well as MD Anderson's internal policies and procedures to the extent they do not conflict with the foregoing subsections (i) and (ii).
perturbation.changed_text: MD Anderson shall, and shall cause each of its employees, agents, contractors, and subcontractors performing Research activities or other obligations under this Agreement, including the Principal Investigator (collectively, "Representatives") to, conduct such activities, and use, store and handle all materials used in the performance of activities under this Agreement and each Study Order, or cause the same to be done, in accordance with (i) all applicable laws, regulations, and guidelines, including, to the extent applicable, the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act ("FFCDA"); the anti-kickback and related provisions of the Social Security Act; the Public Health Services Act; the regulations promulgated by the Food and Drug Administration ("FDA"), including 21 C.F.R. Parts 50, 56, and 58, and, with respect to clinical Studies, the requirements of the Statement of Investigator, FDA Form 1572 (as described in 21 312.53), the terms of which are incorporated by reference into any Study Order pertaining to a clinical Study (and the Principal Investigator for any such clinical Study shall complete, sign, and deliver a Form 1572 to LBIO prior to the commencement of such Study); the United States Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, as amended by the HITECH Act, including the Standards for Privacy of Individually Identifiable Health Information; the EU Data Protection Directive; and all other applicable privacy, security and data protection laws (collectively, this sub-clause (i), "Laws"), and, as applicable, the quality standards of "Good Clinical Practice" (which term shall mean generally accepted good clinical practices including those set out in the current version of the Declaration of Helsinki and the International Conference on Harmonization Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice in force from time to time and FDA's most recent guidance and regulations concerning current Good Clinical Practice), (ii) the provisions of this Agreement (including each applicable Study Order and Protocol), and (iii) all written instruction from LBIO, MD Anderson internal policies and procedures will take priority over any instruction from LBIO in subsections (i) and (ii).
perturbation.explanation: This creates a contradiction. The original text states that MD Anderson must comply with LBIO's written instructions, as long as they do not conflict with applicable laws or the agreement itself. This modification gives MD Anderson's internal policies precedence over LBIO's instructions. This introduces ambiguity, as it is unclear which guidance takes priority when LBIO's instructions and MD Anderson's internal policies conflict, even when the written instructions do not go against existing laws or the initial agreement. This creates an uncertainty in the standards to enforce.

perturbation.original_text: Termination of this Agreement by either Party shall not affect the rights and obligations of the Parties accrued prior to the effective date of termination. No termination of this Agreement, however effectuated, shall release the Parties, the Principal Investigator, or any other Representative of MD Anderson having access to Confidential Information from their respective rights and obligations under Sections 6, 7, and 9.
perturbation.changed_text: Termination of this Agreement by either Party shall not affect the rights and obligations of the Parties accrued prior to the effective date of termination. Termination of this agreement releases the Parties, the Principal Investigator, or any other Representative of MD Anderson from their respective rights and obligations under Sections 6, 7, and 9.
perturbation.explanation: The original section specifies that termination doesn't release parties from confidentiality, invention, and miscellaneous obligations. The modified version directly contradicts this by saying that termination *does* release parties from those same obligations. This conflict makes it unclear whether these clauses survive termination or not, thus leading to uncertainty in enforcement.
